Award.AwardTitle: Carbon Nanotube-Based Sensing Composites: A Novel Distributed Sensing Approach for Structural Health Monitoring

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project proposes to investigate and develop carbon nanotube/polymer-impregnated fabric for structural health monitoring (SHM). The idea is to attach the fabric to a structural member in buildings and bridges to monitor deformations and cracks in the member continuously and trigger an alarm when they exceed a certain critical level. Because the fabric is continuous, the deformations and cracks can be measured on all the surfaces where the fabric is applied. This development, if successful, can be a significant advancement toward sustainable buildings and structures. A particular effort is aimed at recruiting talented students from underrepresented groups and Women in Engineering (WIE) programs. There is a close university/industry interaction which will facilitate rapid technology transfer between basic science and technological applications.

The research focuses on the integration of carbon nanotube-based sensing technology into structural health monitoring (SHM) systems for civil structures and buildings. Carbon nanotube sensing layers consist of a conductive network structure that enables nerve-like distributed sensing capabilities. The sensing concept is based on utilizing electrically conductive carbon nanotube networks integrated into the polymer matrix of a textile composite. Carbon nanotube-based sensors have a number of unique characteristics as compared to traditional SHM sensors, such as strain gages, accelerometers, or displacement sensors, and are extremely well suited for distributed sensing. Preliminary work by has shown that the novel sensor is (1) extremely sensitive to strain and micro-damage, (2) applicable to a wide range of geometries, and (3) robust and functional well into the non-linear structural behavior. Research in sensor processing, characterization and modeling, sensor response and data analysis, and model testing of components as well as complete structures will be performed. The proposed research is a multidisciplinary collaboration and builds upon the strengths of the two investigators in structural health monitoring and structural mechanics and in nanostructured composites and sensors.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated and established the scientific basis for carbon nanotube/polymer-impregnated flexible fabric sensors capable of simultaneous structural rehabilitation and health monitoring of concrete structures. The self-sensing fabric is attached to a structural member in buildings and bridges to provide additional strength while deformations and cracks can be monitored continuously and trigger an alarm when they exceed a certain critical level. Because the sensor is continuous, the deformations and cracks can be measured across large areas where the fabric is applied. This represents a major advance compared to when conventional sensors are used, such as displacement or strain gages, which only provide point-type information. The broader impacts of this research include increasing the safety, reliability, and sustainability of structures ranging from buildings and bridges to aerospace structures. 

The intellectual merit of this research is in expanding the science-base for the use of distributed carbon nanotube-based sensors for integration in real-time quantitative structural health monitoring systems. Through judicious material selection and selective local integration of nanotubes, hierarchical sensing approaches have been established where nanotube composites are applied to existing structures to detect deformation and damage. New analysis techniques have been developed to interpret the data from the sensors to track the location, accumulation, and extent of structural damage. The interdisciplinary research tasks included developing appropriate processing and manufacturing techniques that will allow making large sensors that are applied to concrete. First, the electrical and mechanical response of the sensing fabrics were characterized using small-scale experiments. The influence of temperature and moisture variations, which needs to be known for real-world applications, was also characterized and appropriate correction factors were established. An advanced data interpretation methodology was created that allows to pin-point to where damage on the layer has occurred. Finally, a large sensing fabric was produced and integrated with a structural composite and applied to a 16-foot long reinforced concrete beam to demonstrate the feasibility in a large-scale laboratory setting.

Broader impacts of this research include a significant advancement toward sustainable buildings and structures that are safer and more reliable. A particular effort was aimed at recruiting talented students from underrepresented groups and Women in Engineering (WIE) programs. One PhD student, one M.S. student, and two undergraduate students, one of which was female, participated in the research. The findings of the research were widely disseminated through participation of the team, including the students, at national and international conferences, invited seminars, and refereed journal publications.


Last Modified: 10/29/2016
Modified by: Erik T Thostenson

The self-sensing fabric is attached to a structural member in buildings and bridges to provide additional strength while deformations and cracks can be monitored continuously and trigger an alarm when they exceed a certain critical level. Because the sensor is continuous, the deformations and cracks can be measured across large areas where the fabric is applied. This represents a major advance compared to when conventional sensors are used, such as displacement or strain gages, which only provide point-type information. The broader impacts of this research include increasing the safety, reliability, and sustainability of structures ranging from buildings and bridges to aerospace structures. The intellectual merit of this research is in expanding the science-base for the use of distributed carbon nanotube-based sensors for integration in real-time quantitative structural health monitoring systems. Through judicious material selection and selective local integration of nanotubes, hierarchical sensing approaches have been established where nanotube composites are applied to existing structures to detect deformation and damage. New analysis techniques have been developed to interpret the data from the sensors to track the location, accumulation, and extent of structural damage. The interdisciplinary research tasks included developing appropriate processing and manufacturing techniques that will allow making large sensors that are applied to concrete. First, the electrical and mechanical response of the sensing fabrics were characterized using small-scale experiments. An advanced data interpretation methodology was created that allows to pin-point to where damage on the layer has occurred. Broader impacts of this research include a significant advancement toward sustainable buildings and structures that are safer and more reliable. A particular effort was aimed at recruiting talented students from underrepresented groups and Women in Engineering (WIE) programs. One PhD student, one M.S. student, and two undergraduate students, one of which was female, participated in the research.
